page.title: 17The River Medway
page.content: The River Medway is the chief river of Kent and is about 110km.long.As far up-stream as Snodland there is plenty of water mid-stream even at low tide.The stretch of water between Halling on the west bank and Wouldham on the east bank meanders between muddy banks,widening at Burham.The marshy ground attracts interesting bird-life. On the banks there are cement factories and the remains of old ones. From prehistoric times this stretch of the river has been used for the transportation of heavy loads.In the eighteenth century smuggling was an important pastime.Goods carried included spirits,wine,tea,tobacco and raisins.There are rumours of secret tunnels on both sides of the river. Until the Second World War Spritsail barges were used for trade purposes.
